page.title: 03Ecology of the Nibley area.
page.content: This area, typical of the surrounding Gloucestershire countryside, is well balanced with trees and hedges dividing the fields which support the wide range of natural wildlife. The woodland is fairly dense but kept in order. It consists mainly of beech with a scattering of oak, birch, sycamore and conifers. The woods are inhabited by badgers, foxes and other small rodents. Beaneath the rotting leaf-litter,various species of insects live, feeding off debris and each other. The pathways are wide and well defined. They are kept clear and easy to follow. Pollution is not a real problem at the moment, but the nearby power stations are causing growing concern. This area as a whole is kept free from litter in the streets and countryside.
